chapters.summary: The chapter explains matter, its physical nature, characteristics, states (solid, liquid, gas), and the effect of temperature and pressure on states of matter. Concepts like diffusion, evaporation, and latent heat are introduced.
student_explanation: Everything around us is made of matter.
Matter is made of tiny particles.
Particles of matter attract each other.
Solids have fixed shape, liquids flow, gases spread fast.

key_definitions.definition: Anything that has mass and occupies space.
Mixing of particles from high concentration to low concentration.
Heat required to change state without change in temperature.
Surface phenomenon where liquid converts into vapour.

important_points: Particles of matter have space, motion, and attraction.
Melting point and boiling point are constant for pure substances.
Evaporation causes cooling.

chapters.summary: This chapter explains pure substances, mixtures, solutions, concentration, suspension, colloids, and methods of physical separation like filtration, evaporation, distillation, chromatography, and centrifugation.
student_explanation: Pure substances have only one type of particles.
Mixtures contain two or more substances.

key_definitions.definition: Homogeneous mixture of solute and solvent.

important_points: True solutions do not scatter light.
Colloids show Tyndall effect.
Mixtures can be separated by physical methods.

formulas_and_identities.concentration_formula: Concentration = (Mass of solute / Mass of solution) × 100

chapters.summary: The chapter explains laws of chemical combination, Dalton's atomic theory, atomic and molecular mass, mole concept, and writing chemical formulae.
student_explanation: Laws of chemical combination explain how substances react.

key_definitions.definition: Two or more atoms chemically combined.
Mass of an atom expressed in amu.
Amount of substance containing Avogadro number of particles.

important_points: Chemical formula shows types and number of atoms.
Molecular mass = sum of atomic masses.

chapters.summary: This chapter covers discoveries related to the atom, Thomson, Rutherford, and Bohr models, atomic number, mass number, isotopes, and isobars.
student_explanation: Atom has electrons, protons, and neutrons.

key_definitions.definition: Number of protons in an atom.
Atoms with same atomic number but different mass number.
Atoms with same mass number but different atomic number.

important_points: Electrons occupy fixed energy levels.
Isotopes have similar chemical properties.

chapters.summary: This chapter introduces the cell, its structure, cell organelles, and differences between plant and animal cells.
student_explanation: Cell is the basic unit of life.

key_definitions.definition: Structural and functional unit of life.

important_points: Plant cells have cell wall, chloroplast, and large vacuole.
Animal cells lack cell wall.

cell_theory: All living beings are made of cells.

chapters.summary: Explanation of plant and animal tissues, their types, structure, and functions.
student_explanation: Tissues are groups of similar cells.
Plants have meristematic and permanent tissues.
Animals have epithelial, connective, muscular, and nervous tissues.

key_definitions.definition: Group of cells performing same function.

important_points: Xylem and phloem are vascular tissues.
Muscle tissues help in movement.

chapters.summary: Introduction to distance, displacement, speed, velocity, acceleration, and graphical representation of motion.
important_points: Distance-time graph shows speed.
Area under velocity-time graph gives displacement.

chapters.summary: Newton’s laws of motion, inertia, momentum, and relation between force and acceleration are discussed.
student_explanation: Momentum depends on mass and velocity.

key_definitions.definition: Tendency of body to resist change in motion.

important_points: Action and reaction forces are equal and opposite.
More mass → more inertia.

chapters.summary: Newton’s law of gravitation, free fall, mass vs weight, and buoyancy are introduced.

key_definitions.definition: Force with which Earth attracts a body (mg).

important_points: Gravitational force acts between all masses.
Thrust and pressure affect fluids.

chapters.summary: Introduction to work, kinetic and potential energy, and law of conservation of energy.
student_explanation: Work is done when force causes displacement.
Kinetic energy is energy of motion.
important_points: Energy cannot be created or destroyed.
Different forms of energy can convert into each other.

chapters.summary: Explanation of production of sound, propagation of sound, frequency, amplitude, speed, and applications like SONAR.
student_explanation: Sound needs a medium to travel.
important_points: Sound cannot travel in vacuum.
Ultrasound is used in medical imaging.

chapters.summary: This chapter explains crop production, management, protection, and enhancement of food resources.
student_explanation: Animals and plants need proper nutrition.
Manure and fertilizers improve soil fertility.

key_definitions.definition: Organic matter used for soil fertility.
Chemical substance to increase soil nutrients.

important_points: Irrigation is essential for crops.
Animal husbandry improves food production.
